facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 816 of 1973 filed under Section 116-A of the Representation of People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 816 of 1973.  Appeal under Section 116-A of the Representation of People Act, 1951 from the Judgment and Order dated the 12th March, 1973 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh in Election Petition No. 7 of 1972.

facts.text: Punjab and Haryana High Court delivered Judgment and Order dated 12th March 1973 in Election Petition No. 7 of 1972 setting aside the appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Section 116-A of the Representation of People Act, 1951 from the Judgment and Order dated the 12th March, 1973 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh in Election Petition No. 7 of 1972.  S. Bindra, R. H. Dhebar, B. S. Malik, P. R. Ramasesh and C. Bhatia, for the Appellant.

facts.text: General election held on March 11, 1972 for Haryana Assembly from Nuh constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- KRISHNA IYER, J.-By a plurality of less than 2,000 votes the appellant was declared elected from the Nuh companystituency to the Haryana Assembly in the general election held on March 11, 1972.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected from Nuh constituency by plurality of less than 2,000 votes over first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- KRISHNA IYER, J.-By a plurality of less than 2,000 votes the appellant was declared elected from the Nuh companystituency to the Haryana Assembly in the general election held on March 11, 1972. lie was an Independent candidate while his main rival, the first respondent, represented the Indian National Congress.

facts.text: Appellant was Independent candidate, first respondent from Indian National Congress.

anchor.surface_text: lie was an Independent candidate while his main rival, the first respondent, represented the Indian National Congress. There were three others in the field two of whom were independents and the third a Jan Sangh numberinee-all of them polled poorly.

facts.text: First respondent filed election petition challenging appellant's election on grounds of corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: Anyway, the disappointed first respondent hastened to challenge the appellants election on various grounds of currupt practices. The High Court has upheld a few of them and voided the appellants election, a miss being as good as a mile.

facts.text: High Court set aside appellant's election finding corrupt practices proved.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld a few of them and voided the appellants election, a miss being as good as a mile. The campaign pollutants must be kept down at the polls if electoral disenchantment is number to grip the general companymunity.

facts.text: Handbill Exhibit P.W.4/3 existed before 12th March 1972 and was supplied by returned candidate (appellant) to agents for distribution among Muslim voters.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has wound up thus My companyclusions from the evidence discussed under this issue may be summed up as follows Handbill Exhibit P. W.4/3 was in existence before the 12th of March, 1972. The returned candidate supplied companyies of the handbill to his agents and workers for distribution amongst Muslim voters.

facts.text: Returned candidate and supporters made appeal to Muslim voters on 9th and 10th March 1972 to vote for him as true Muslim and against petitioner as kafir, through speeches and handbill PW4/3 in 10 villages.

anchor.surface_text: The returned candidate and his supporters with his companysent, made an appeal to Muslim voters to vote for the returned candidate because he was a true Muslim whereas the peti- tioner was a kafir. This appeal was made on the 9th and 10 th of March, 1972, through speeches delivered by the returned candidate and his supporters and by distribution of handbill Exhibit P. W. 4/3, in the following villages of the Nuh Assembly companystituency Notki Gohana, Khedli Nuh, Mewli, Malab, Nagina, Karherrha, Pinangwan, Bhadas and Gliagas.

facts.text: Villages where appeals made: Notki, Gohana, Khedli, Nuh, Mewli, Malab, Nagina, Karherrha, Pinangwan, Bhadas, Gliagas.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal was made on the 9th and 10 th of March, 1972, through speeches delivered by the returned candidate and his supporters and by distribution of handbill Exhibit P. W. 4/3, in the following villages of the Nuh Assembly companystituency Notki Gohana, Khedli Nuh, Mewli, Malab, Nagina, Karherrha, Pinangwan, Bhadas and Gliagas.

facts.text: High Court found appeal to religion under section 123(3) committed by returned candidate.

anchor.surface_text: It is companyceded before me that the appeal just above found by me to have been made by the returned candidate was an appeal to vote for the returned candidate and to refrain from voting for the petitioner on the ground of their religion, for the furtherance of the prospects of the election of the returned candidate and for prejudicially affecting the election of the petitioner so that it falls within the ambit of the companyrupt practice detailed in section 123  3  of the Act, which companyrupt practice the returned candidate must be held to have companymitted.

facts.text: High Court found publication of statements in handbill PW4/3 by returned candidate and Shri Tayyab Hussain with consent amounted to undue influence under section 123(2).

anchor.surface_text: the publication that the returned candidate and others in handbill Exhibit P. W. 4/3 amounted to the companymission of the companyrupt practice of undue influence as defined in section 123 2  of the Act. Having found that the returned candidate and others with his companysent companymitted the companyrupt practice- defined in clauses  1 ,  2 ,  3  and  4  of section 123 of the Act, I accept the petition and declare the election of the returned candidate to the Haryana Legislative Assembly from the. Nub Assembly companystituency to be void.

facts.text: High Court found on 14th February 1972, returned candidate placed car No. DLF 675 at disposal of respondent No. 3 with promise to meet expenses.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the above discussion I find it proved that on the 14th of February 1972, the returned candidate placed at the disposal of respondent No. 3 Car No. DLF 675 with a promise that these expense incurred in hiring the car and running it in companynection with the election campaign of respondent No. 3 would be met by the returned candidate.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds charge of bribery with car to respondent No.3 not proved under s.123(1).

anchor.surface_text: The serious scrutiny of law and facts expected of election tribunals before unseating a returned candidate is wanting in the High Courts finding and we hold that, suspicions apart, the charge of bribing Sohanlal into fighting a futile battle has number been brought home as required by s. 123 1  of the Act

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts that handbill Ex PW4/3 was printed and distributed by appellant among constituents before poll.

anchor.surface_text: In the ultimate analysis we hold that the appellant did get the handbills, Exhibits P. W. 4/3 printed and distributed among his companystituents. Thereby he made statements which were untrue and which he did number believe to be true and knew to be false, about the rival candidate with a view to diminish the latters prospects in the election.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds handbill constitutes appeal to religion under s.123(3) and false statements under s.123(4).

anchor.surface_text: We further hold that Exhibit P. W. 4/3 companystitutes an appeal to religion for the purpose of voting for and against. Thus, under these two heads, a companytravention under s. 123 of the Act has been companymitted and for these two companyrupt practices the unseating of the appellant becomes inevitable

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds two corrupt practices sufficient to void election.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, while number endorsing the entire findings of the High Court, we uphold two of its major findings-of companyrupt practices-sufficient to undo the election of the appellant.

facts.text: Nuh is a Muslim predominant constituency.

anchor.surface_text: In a loose sense, Nuh is a Muslim companystituency by which we mean that the voting strength of the Muslims is preponderant. Both the candidates are Muslims and, indeed, to some extent the Islamic dosage of each candidate has itself been highlighted in the Election Petition as a bone of companytention in the poll companyfrontation, as will be presently discussed.

facts.text: Both candidates are Muslims.

anchor.surface_text: Both the candidates are Muslims and, indeed, to some extent the Islamic dosage of each candidate has itself been highlighted in the Election Petition as a bone of companytention in the poll companyfrontation, as will be presently discussed.

facts.text: Appellant previously elected from same constituency in 1967 as Deputy Minister.

anchor.surface_text: It also happens that while the appellant had been a Deputy Minister when he was elected to the Haryana Legislative Assembly last from the same companystituency in 1967, at the following general election in May 1968 to the same Assembly  before its term the Assembly was dissolved and the number-Congress Government went out of office  the first respondent was elected and he became a Member of the Cabinet formed by the Congress party.

issues.text: Whether the appellant committed the corrupt practice under s.123(1) of the Act by placing a car at the disposal of Respondent No.3 with promise of expenses to induce continuance as candidate rather than withdrawal

anchor.surface_text: the narrow point that survives for our scrutiny as to whether the appellant did commit the corrupt practice under s. 123 1  of the Representation of People Act, 1951  the Act , for short , by placing at the disposal of candidate Respondent 3, car L.F. 675 and promising him the hire charges and running expenses thereof with a view to his continuance as candidate, the ultimate gain being the seduction of the Harijan electors away from the Congress candidate

issues.text: Whether handbill Exhibit P.W.4/3 was in existence before the 12th of March, 1972 and distributed by the returned candidate and his supporters

anchor.surface_text: My conclusions from the evidence discussed under this issue may be summed up as follows Handbill Exhibit P. W.4/3 was in existence before the 12th of March, 1972. The returned candidate supplied copies of the handbill to his agents and workers for distribution amongst Muslim voters.

issues.text: Whether the publication and distribution of the handbill constitutes appeal to vote or refrain from voting on ground of religion under section 123(3) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: section 123  3  of the Act, which corrupt practice the returned candidate must be held to have committed. The issue is accordingly found in favour of the petitioner.

issues.text: Whether the statements in the handbill about the rival candidate constitute corrupt practice of publication of false statements regarding personal character and conduct under section 123(4) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Having found that the returned candidate and others with his consent committed the corrupt practice- defined in clauses  1 ,  2 ,  3  and  4  of section 123 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: the publication that the returned candidate and others in handbill Exhibit P. W. 4/3 amounted to the commission of the corrupt practice of undue influence as defined in section 123 2  of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: s. 144 Cr. P. C. had been clamped down on the whole constituency... s. 126 of the Act prohibits holding of public meetings within 48 hours of the close of the poll.

issues.text: Whether a nexus is established between the handbills and the appellant such that their pre-poll circulation by him or his agents is proved

anchor.surface_text: The only question that remains is whether a nexus is established between these handbills and the appellant and the factum of their prepoll circulation by him or his agents is proved.

issues.text: Whether the High Court complied with s.99 by naming all persons guilty of corrupt practices after notice and opportunity

anchor.surface_text: Half serious apprehensions are not undue influence... No one... will shiver with fear that a candidate... will force down his throat distasteful pork. Such chimerical apprehensions are unreal

arguments.claim: Car provision to resp3 not bribery under s.123(1) absent inducement not to withdraw

anchor.surface_text: it is not every help... that constitutes corrupt practice. Such financial aid must be to induce the latter not to withdraw... the key question is... whether the provision of the car was to prod the candidate not to withdraw

holdings.text: The charge of bribing Sohanlal (Respondent No.3) by providing car and expenses under s.123(1) has not been proved as required.

anchor.surface_text: The serious scrutiny of law and facts expected of election tribunals before unseating a returned candidate is wanting in the High Courts finding and we hold that, suspicions apart, the charge of bribing Sohanlal into fighting a futile battle has not been brought home as required by s. 123(1) of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof that car provided to induce continuance rather than withdrawal; evidence insufficient, suspicions not enough; strict proof required in quasi-criminal proceedings.

holdings.text: Handbill Exhibit P.W.4/3 existed before poll, printed and distributed by appellant or his agents among constituents.

anchor.surface_text: In the ultimate analysis we hold that the appellant did get the handbills, Exhibits P. W. 4/3 printed and distributed among his constituents. Thereby he made statements which were untrue and which he did not believe to be true

holdings.reasoning_summary: Official records Ex.P.18, P.19 with endorsements under s.35 Evidence Act prove pre-poll existence; chain of circumstances links to appellant; motive and prior circulation probable.

holdings.text: Statements in handbill Exhibit P.W.4/3 are untrue, not believed true by appellant, made to diminish rival's prospects, constituting corrupt practice under s.123(4).

anchor.surface_text: and which he did not believe to be true and knew to be false, about the rival candidate with a view to diminish the latters prospects in the election. We further hold that Exhibit P. W. 4/3 constitutes an appeal to religion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner swore statements false; appellant admitted not believing them true; published knowing false to harm rival.

holdings.text: Handbill Exhibit P.W.4/3 constitutes appeal to religion for voting for/against candidates under s.123(3).

anchor.surface_text: We further hold that Exhibit P. W. 4/3 constitutes an appeal to religion for the purpose of voting for and against. Thus, under these two heads, a contravention under s. 123 of the Act has been committed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Portrays rival as kafir/pork-eater, self as true Muslim; invokes popular sentiment tied to religion per Kultar Singh precedent, despite diet not core tenet.

holdings.text: Statements in handbill do not amount to undue influence under s.123(2).

anchor.surface_text: Half serious apprehensions are not undue influence by any standards. No one in India in the 70s will shiver with fear that a candidate, when he wins an election, will force down his throat distasteful pork.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Apprehensions of forced pork-eating are chimerical, half-serious, not real compulsion or interference with free electoral right.

holdings.text: No public meetings held violating s.126 RP Act or s.144 CrPC; impromptu small gatherings not violations.

anchor.surface_text: What we see from the evidence is that there were no regular meetings prearranged and public. It was more a case of the appellant running around from place to place, meeting persons who gathered when he went

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prohibitory order in force; evidence shows no formal public meetings, only spontaneous small groups common on election eve, winked at by police.

holdings.text: Two corrupt practices under s.123(3) and (4) proved; sufficient to void appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, under these two heads, a contravention under s. 123 of the Act has been committed and for these two corrupt practices the unseating of the appellant becomes inevitable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Single corrupt practice voids election; two proved via handbill, upholding High Court on these despite rejecting others.

holdings.text: High Court erred under s.99(a)(ii) by not naming all guilty persons after notice and opportunity per proviso and natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Having found the commission of corrupt practices by the appellant, Tayyab Hussain... it was the statutory duty of the Judge to name all those who have been proved... s. 99(a)(ii). The serious disqualification... proviso to s. 99(a) inhibits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory duty to name guilty non-parties only after notice/opportunity; High Court failed, violating natural justice.

holdings.text: Appellate court under s.116A can re-appraise evidence but slow to disturb trial court fact findings unless perverse or unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: The-correct appellate perspective in an election case has been indicated by this Court... re-appraise the evidence and reverse the trial courts findings of fact. But... subject to certain inherent limitations

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents like Laxminarayan, Kanhaiyalal; burden on appellant to show trial error; applied throughout.

holdings.text: Strict proof beyond reasonable doubt-like standard required for corrupt practices in election petitions (quasi-criminal).

anchor.surface_text: election petitions where corrupt practices are imputed must be regarded as proceedings of a quasi-criminal nature wherein strict proof is necessary. The burden is therefore heavy on him who assails an election

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heavy onus on petitioner; applied to scrutinize evidence mercilessly before unseating returned candidate.

anchor.surface_text: In Laxminarayan V. Returning Officer 1  the implied limitations on the appellate power under S.116A were stated thus It can re-appraise the evidence and reverse the trial

precedents.cited_proposition: implied limitations on the appellate power under S.116A: appellate court can re-appraise evidence but subject to inherent limitations, burden on appellant to show where trial court went wrong

anchor.surface_text: In Karemores Case 2  this position was re- stated thus Before a finding of fact by a Trial Court can be set aside it must be established that the Trial Judges findings were clearly unsound, perverse or have been based on grounds which are unsatisfactory by reason of material inconsistencies or inaccuracies.

precedents.cited_proposition: before setting aside trial court finding of fact, must be clearly unsound, perverse, or based on unsatisfactory grounds

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J., in Harcharan Singhs Case  1  observed The primary purpose of the diverse provisions of the election law which may appear to be technical is to safeguard the purity of the election process, and the Courts will number ordinarily minimise their operation.

precedents.cited_proposition: primary purpose of election law provisions is to safeguard purity of election process; courts will not minimise their operation

precedents.citation: Ambika Saran Singh v. Mahant Mahadev Nand Giri 1

anchor.surface_text: Their evidence has naturally to be viewed with circumspection, but number dismissed outright See Ambika Saran Singh v. Mahant Mahadev Nand Giri 1 . But more curious is the turn-coat type of witnesses who claimed to be and often were the polling agents,

precedents.case_name: Ambika Saran Singh v. Mahant Mahadev Nand Giri
precedents.cited_proposition: partisan witnesses' evidence to be viewed with circumspection but not dismissed outright

anchor.surface_text: The whole companystituency is silently present before us it must be remembered  See observations of Dua I, J. in I.L.R. 1969 I Punj 625.  We must emphasize the danger of believing at its face value oral evidence in an election case without the backing of sure circumstances or indubitable documents.

precedents.cited_proposition: danger of believing oral evidence without backing; constituency present

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless, having regard to the ruling in Kultar Singh v. Mukhtiar Singh 1  and the popular sentiment tied up rightly or wrongly with Muslim religion, we do number disagree with the view of the High Court and the stand of both companynsel.

precedents.cited_proposition: regarding appeal to religion in context of dietary practices

anchor.surface_text: He drew our attention to the observations of Grover, J. in P. Belagali v. B. D. Jatti 1  which make a vain echo in the present case. The learned Judge there observed Free and fair elections are the very foundation of democratic institutions

precedents.case_name: P. Belagali v. B. D. Jatti
precedents.cited_proposition: free and fair elections foundation of democracy; elections must seem fair, officers should not interfere especially for ministers

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the observations made in Balwant Singh v. Lakshmi Narain 1  and are number deterred from companysidering the evidence of P. W. 54 and others similarly circumstanced. No prejudice on account of deficiency in particulars is made out.

precedents.citation: B. Rajagopala Rao v. N. G. Ranga 1

anchor.surface_text: We are aware, as numbericed in B. Rajagopala Rao v. N. G. Ranga 1  that the enemies of a winning candidate may get such numberices printed and distributed as part of the strategy of subverting an unfavourable election result.

anchor.surface_text: We are number blind to the possibility of executive officers designing to oblige Ministers in elections as happened in Ambika Saran Singhs Case Supra . Maybe, there is some embarrassment for weak officials when sitting Ministers are candidates
